generif.text: fundamentally conserved mechanism for high affinity copper uptake through the Ctr proteins in yeast and humans
biochemical characterization and subcellular localization

observations demonstrate that, although Ctr1 is critical for both cellular copper uptake and embryonic development, mammals possess additional biochemically distinct functional copper transport activities
Results suggest that human copper transporter 1 (CTR1) spans the membrane at least six times, permitting formation of a channel, which is consistent with its proposed role as a copper transporter.
hCtr1-mediated copper uptake into mammalian cells is regulated by a post-translational mechanism involving copper-stimulated endocytosis and degradation of the transporter
there are common biochemical mechanisms regulate both transport and trafficking functions of hCtr1
there is a direct interaction between cisplatin and the hCtr1 protein; cisplatin and copper have distinct biochemical consequences on this transporter
Internalization of endogenous human Ctr1 in response to elevated extracellular copper levels does not play a significant regulatory role in copper homeostasis.
Hormones have a role in the formation of the active hCTR1 protein in human placental cells.
formation of a putative pore for metal ions at the interface of three identical subunits deviates from the structural design of typical primary and secondary active transporters
hCTR1 plays a key role in the physiologically important delivery of copper from blood to intracellular proteins, whereas its role in the initial apical uptake of dietary copper is indirect.
The results of NMR methods and site-directed mutagenesis of the two cysteine residues demonstrate that Cys-189 but not Cys-161 is essential for both dimer formation and proper folding of the protein.

structure of the human CTR1 protein solved by electron crystallography to an in plane resolution of 7 A

Results describe the interactions of a peptide corresponding to the N-terminal domain of the human copper transporter 1 with cisplatin and its analogues, at the molecular level.
Data indicate that human copper transporter 1 cleavage occurs in a late endosomal, Rab9-positive compartment prior to delivery of the transporter to the plasma membrane.
Copper-dependent internalization and recycling of hCTR1 provides an acute and reversible mechanism for the regulation of cellular copper entry.
findings reveal a high level of conservation between the mammalian and insect Ctr1-type copper importers

Identified as dominant hinge regions, CTR1's MxxxM and GxxxG motifs were shown to have significant roles in functional movements characterized by the two slowest modes of motion.
Ctr1 is an important transport protein in the accumulation of silver in mammalian cells.

There was little difference in rates/kinetics of uptake of copper in the Ctr1+/+ and -/- cells. Endocytosis was not involved.
CTR1 plays an essential role in cisplatin toxicity and could be considered as a predictor for pretreatment evaluation in lung cancer patients.

The cells expressing the hCTR1 mutants of histidine-rich motifs in the N-terminus (H22-24A, NHA) resulted in a higher basal copper level in the steady state compared to those expressing wild-type protein.

Structure of CTR1 confirms that two triads of methionine residues delineate the intramembranous region of the transporter, and further identifies two additional methionine triads that are located in the extracellular N-terminal part of the transporter.
basal expression of Ctr1 is regulated by HIF2alpha; however, the induction by hypoxia is a HIF2alpha-independent event

Duodenal CTR1 mRNA and protein expression was decreased in Wilson's disease patients, while ATP7A mRNA and protein production was increased. This can be a defense mechanism against systemic copper overload resulting from functional impairment of ATP7B.
Knockdown of CTR1 expression in human umbilical cord endothelial cells increases cell proliferation and migration.
Cisplatin transcriptionally induces the expression of human Ctr1 in time- and concentration-dependent manners.

Extracellular copper concentrations regulate the levels of CTR1 through internalisation and degradation, the addition of prolactin, inhibits the degradation of CTR1, thus promoting copper uptake by mammary epithelial cells.

BP.term: vascular endothelial growth factor receptor-2 signaling pathway

name: solute carrier family 31 member 1

reactome.name: Transport of bile salts and organic acids, metal ions and amine compounds

summary: The protein encoded by this gene is a high-affinity copper transporter found in the cell membrane. The encoded protein functions as a homotrimer to effect the uptake of dietary copper. [provided by RefSeq, Aug 2011].
